item.title: Putin Warns of Restricting Natural Gas Supply to Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin and other senior Russian officials also reiterated the Kremlin’s contention that Ukraine owes Russia more than $16 billion in unpaid gas bills and other debts.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: India Ink: India Election Digest: April 10
item.description: A roundup of the top election-related news for Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Officials checked electronic voting machines before they were sent to polling stations in New Delhi.

item.title: Flight Search Brings Satellite Company Unaccustomed Fame
item.description: Inmarsat, the company keeping tabs on the flow of information about Flight 370, has found itself thrust, uncomfortably, into the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Japan Pushes Plan to Stockpile Plutonium, Despite Proliferation Risks
item.description: Japan is set to push ahead with a program that would produce new stockpiles of weapon-grade plutonium, creating a proliferation risk for decades to come.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: The lightly guarded Rokkasho Reprocessing Plant, where Japan stores much of its plutonium.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Can China Cast Off Despotism?
item.description: A relentless parade of political trials raises a giant question: As China revels in its growing power, is it able or willing to discard ancient habits?
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Russia Didn’t Share All Details on Boston Bombing Suspect, Report Says
item.description: Two years before the bombings, Russia declined to give the F.B.I. information that most likely would have prompted deeper scrutiny of Tamerlan Tsarnaev, an inspector general’s review said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:credit: Julia Malakie/The Sun of Lowell, via Associated Press

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Deadly Car Bomb Blasts Hit Homs
item.description: Two car bombs exploded minutes apart near a shop in the central Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, killing at least 25 people, state news media and an antigovernment monitoring group reported.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: After Optimism of More Pings, Reality of Long Jet Search Settles In
item.description: Specialists in ocean exploration and recovery cautioned that a successful identification of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370’s wreckage might take weeks or months.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: A version of this torpedo-like, sonar-equipped vehicle, made by Bluefin Robotics, of Quincy, Mass., may be used to search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, if signals turn out to be authentic.

item.title: Mechanics of the Plane Search, Explained
item.description: How the multinational team off the coast of Australia is continuing the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

item.title: World Briefing: Central African Republic: Envoy Urges Support for Peacekeeping Troops
item.description: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, on Wednesday urged more support for existing African and French troops in the Central African Republic on the eve of a United Nations vote to create a peacekeeping mission.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Samantha Power, the American ambassador to the United Nations, in March.

item.title: In Eastern Ukraine, a One-Building, Pro-Russia Realm Persists Despite Criticism
item.description: A group of protesters who have seized the government headquarters in Donetsk, Ukraine, was urged by local politicians to give up and hand over their weapons.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A version of the flag of the Donetsk People’s Republic hung in an occupied government building.

item.title: U.S. Pair Can’t Leave Qatar Amid Appeal
item.description: Sentenced to three years in their daughter’s death, Matthew and Grace Huang of Los Angeles have been denied permission to travel.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grace and Matthew Huang, in Doha, shown in late March, fear being rearrested this week in their adopted daughter’s death.

item.title: Gasps in Court as Prosecution Prods Pistorius
item.description: While cross-examining the athlete Oscar Pistorius, on trial for his girlfriend’s death, the prosecutor displayed a photograph of her bloodied head and all but ordered the defendant to look.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius leaving the courthouse in Pretoria on Wednesday.

item.title: Berlin Journal: Berlin’s Over-Budget, Behind-Schedule Airport Becomes an Attraction
item.description: Berlin’s new airport is attracting tourists after a series of delays and bungles have driven its cost billions of dollars over budget and pushed its opening back indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS COTTRELL
item.media:description: Berlin’s new airport is attracting tourists after a series of delays and bungles have pushed its opening back indefinitely.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Ebola Is Not the Next Pandemic
item.description: But that doesn’t make it any less horrific for the poor West Africans who get it.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID QUAMMEN

item.title: The Lede: Artists Try to Prick Conscience of Drone Operators With Giant Portrait of Orphan in Pakistani Field
item.description: A campaign started this week, “Not a Bug Splat,” sought to draw attention to the human cost of American drone strikes in Pakistan, and to communicate directly with the pilots who guide the bombers to their targets by remote control.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A new art installation unveiled in Pakistan this week features a huge image of a child reportedly orphaned in a drone strike in 2009.

item.title: Leader Tightens Hold on Power in North Korea
item.description: Kim Jong-un was re-elected as head of his country’s top governing agency as its rubber-stamp Parliament met to help consolidate his power by filling top leadership posts vacated in recent purges.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: At War Blog: Despite Doubts, a Vote Worth Casting
item.description: An Afghan journalist recalls his conflicted feelings toward the nation’s first peaceful, democratic transition of power.
item.dc:creator: By ALI M. LATIFI
item.media:description: Ali M. Latifi, at left, and his friends after voting in Kabul on April 5.

item.title: Greece Dives Back Into the Bond Market
item.description: The plan to sell the first long-term bonds in four years is a symbolic turnaround for Greece, even if legions of jobless Greeks are not cheering.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: The headquarters of Greece's central bank in Athens. Officials announced plans to sell long-term bonds for the first time since Greece was granted 240 billion euros’ worth of international bailouts.

item.title: World Briefing : Deadly Wave of Blasts Hits Baghdad
item.description: Eight car bombs and two mortar shells killed as many as 25 people in attacks around the city, according to security personnel.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Deadly Blast at Fruit Market Shatters Calm in Pakistan’s Capital
item.description: The death toll is expected to rise in the Islamabad attack, which came while the Taliban, which denied any role in the blast, were in talks with the government.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: British Culture Secretary Quits Amid Uproar Over Expenses
item.description: Maria Miller had apologized in Parliament for having overclaimed expenses, but by speaking for just 32 seconds, she prompted an avalanche of criticism.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Maria Miller, Britain's culture secretary, left the prime minister's office after a cabinet meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 9
item.description: A member of an insurgent group which has currently suspended operation as part of an agreement with the government, took guard at a polling booth in Manipur.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A member of Kuki National Front, an insurgent group which has currently suspended operation as part of an agreement with the government, guarding a polling booth at Natheljang, Manipur.

item.title: Britain Increasingly Invokes Power to Disown Its Citizens
item.description: The government’s ability to revoke citizenship, and the fact it has used that ability against people who were later killed in drone strikes, has fueled concern.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Germans Loosen Their Purse Strings
item.description: Fresh statistics on German trade show a sharp increase in imports from the euro zone and the broader European Union.
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
